Hi Ron,

 

I think in the case of your two tsuba, niku-bori would be the correct term,
but, I could be wrong. Sukidashi-bori and sukidashi takabori are used when
there is carving that digs downward into the flat surface of the tsuba and
creates high relief carvings. Such carving typically does not include
sukashi work.

 

Gordon

 

  _____  

From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Ron Hartmann
Sent: Friday, April 04, 2008 10:48 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba carving terminology

 

One more example tsuba has been added to my photos - Ron STL album - tsuba
#627 and 227 are the ones I'm referring to. 

Tsuba 227 design is all made (carved) below its plate surface the same as
627 except this one is more elaborately done with the plum blossom branch
design. 

Also an interesting tsuba that has a Choshu design but the work is much more
thin and delicate and looks more Kyoto-something to me...could it be
Kyo-Shoami? Again...I'm looking for terminology here. 

Ron
STL

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Ron Hartmann 
To: nihontostudy 
Sent: Thursday, April 03, 2008 8:40 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Tsuba carving terminology

Hi all - 

What is the Japanese name (term) for sunken relief carved design on tsuba?
I'm talking about the design being made by carving the plate surface away.
The tsuba I'm looking at has been posted under photos...

http://tinyurl. <http://tinyurl.com/2jq42a> com/2jq42a

and shows a 24-petal kiku sukashi where the petals are rounded down below
the surface of the rim and overall plate. (In this case, the tsuba is
actually tapered, the flat edge being 1 mm less than the seppa-dai surface.)
In the Boston book Ogawa called this sukidashi takabori in the Hayne/Harvie
study book it seems to be called horiage (if I'm understanding the
description correction) and also another term which I can't find right now. 

Is there a common name for this type of sunken relief carving? 

Ron
STL
